2. A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of tooth sensitivity when eating citrus fruits and drinking wine, which has progressively worsened over the past year. She notes that her front teeth look shorter and feel rough along the biting edges. On dental examination, there is notable enamel loss exposing the smooth, yellowish dentine with concave erosive lesions on the palatal surfaces of upper incisors. She admits to drinking several cups of lemon-infused water daily and has a history of frequent vomiting episodes related to an eating disorder diagnosed five years ago. There is no significant plaque or calculus visible, and caries are minimal. The dental findings combined with her dietary habits and history indicate dentine erosion primarily caused by intrinsic acid exposure from repeated vomiting and extrinsic acid intake. She is advised to modify her diet, use desensitizing toothpaste, and consult her physician for management of her eating disorder. Follow-up will monitor erosion progression and reinforce preventive strategies.
